course_title: Interdisciplinary Sidecar: American Women and Zionism
class_notes:
Title: American Women and Zionism
This course is an intersection point between Kate Rosenblatt's course on Jewish Women in the Modern World (Religion) and Geoff Levin's course on US-Israel Relations (MESAS). Our sidecar course will use the lens of gender to explore how American women of all
backgrounds engaged with the long history of Zionist organizing in
support of a Jewish homeland. Some of the topics we'd like to include are:
the role of Hadassah: The Women's Zionist Organization of America, Arab
American women's activism, intra-Jewish debates around anti- and non-
Zionism, evangelical Christian women's support for Israel, and Zionist
discourses of antisemitism. Given the high-pitched tenor of conversation
around Zionism on American college campuses, we hope that our sidecar
course will provide space for productive and intellectually engaging
conversations. It will also fit into the Tam Institute for Jewish Studies
thematic framing for the academic year on Gender and Reproduction."
course_description: A side-car course brings together a subset of students from two courses that overlap in methodologies, topics, etc., to create a short interdisciplinary course that runs simultaneously with its two sponsoring courses. One credit, S/U only. Schedule and format arranged by sponsoring professors.
